Wrap-up

Why is good the best possible performance important?

  • Usability, Accessibility
  • Slow WiFi
  • GPRS/Edge/3G connections (e.g. in subways)
  • Roaming
  • Conversion rates
  • Limited dataplans

The numbers

Websites keep getting fatter and fatter

technology end 2013 end 2014 increase
HTML 57Kb 59Kb +4%
CSS 46Kb 57Kb +24%
JavaScript 276Kb 295Kb +7%
Images 1,030Kb 1,243Kb +21%
Flash 87Kb 76Kb -13%
Other 205Kb 223Kb +9%
Total 1,701Kb 1,953Kb +15%

http://www.sitepoint.com/average-page-weight-increases-15-2014

Wrap-up

How can you measure performance?

  • DevTools
  • Google PageSpeed Insights
  • WebPagetest
  • yslow

What is good performance?

Critical path

14kb

delivering the critical-path view (above the fold) in the first 14kb of the page

Pageload

in under 1 second

1.0 second is how long you have for the user’s state of flow to remain uninterrupted

SpeedIndex

under 1000

The Speed Index is the average time at which visible parts of the page are displayed. It is expressed in milliseconds and dependent on size of the view port.

Smooth Animation/Scrolling

60fps

Each frame completes in less than 16.66 milliseconds.

Performance Budget

Set it before you start designing.

A performance budget is just what it sounds like: you set a “budget” on your page and do not allow the page to exceed that.

Tim Kadlec

Performance Budget

Metrics

  1. Milestone timings

    eg. Load time, domContentLoaded, Time to render

  2. SpeedIndex

  3. Quantity based metrics

    eg. Total number of requests, Overall page weight, Total image weight

  4. Rule based metrics

    eg. PageSpeed score, YSlow score

Performance Budget

Comparison with competitors

Performance Budget

What do you do when you exceed the budget?

  1. Optimize an existing feature or asset on the page.

  2. Remove an existing feature or asset from the page.

  3. Don’t add the new feature or asset.

Image optimization

Image optimization

Image file size

Desktop and Mobile each with
4080.964 KB (~4.1 MB)
images

Optimization Step 1

Lossy and lossless image compression

For example: ImageAlpha (lossy) and ImageOptim (lossless)

Optimization Step 1

File Compression

4080.964 KB (~4.1 MB)
→
2020,915 KB (~2 MB)

Image optimization

Image size

Desktop and Mobile each with
2020,915 KB (~2 MB)
images

Optimization Step 2

Save images in the correct size

2020,915 KB (~2 MB)
→
1131,866 KB (~1.2 MB)

Responsive image

Optimization Step 3

Responsive images

<img src="small.jpg" srcset="large.jpg 1024w,
                             medium.jpg 640w, 
                             small.jpg 320w" 
                      sizes="320px" alt="A rad wolf">

Optimization Step 3

~301 KB

Image optimization

Smaller Imageformats

Images size Mobile: ~301 KB
Images size Desktop: 1131,866 KB (~1.2 MB)

Optimization Step 4

WebP

  • Imageformat developed by Google
  • Currently only supported in Chrome, Opera, Android Webkit, Chrome Android
  • Sometimes bigger than the original file

Optimization Step 4

Webp & picture

<picture> 
    <source type="image/webp" 
            srcset="small.webp 320w, big.webp 768w">

    <img src="small.jpg" 
          srcset="small.jpg 320w, big.jpg 768w" alt="Image">
</picture>

Optimization Step 4

Webp

Images size Mobile:

~301 KB
→
~176 KB

Optimization Step 4

Webp

Images size Desktop:

~1.2 MB
→
~522 KB

Image optimization

  • Adjust images sizes
  • Serve images responsivly
  • Use best possible image format

Combine CSS Files

into fewer files

Remove unused CSS

There's always some unused CSS

15 KB Custom CSS
26 KB Bootstrap theme
147 KB Bootstrap
3 KB Validation plugin

Total: ~192 KB CSS

Remove unused CSS

Check pages for unused CSS

Chrome Dev Tools -> Audits -> Run

Optimization Step 6

Remove unused CSS

UnCss is a tool that removes unused CSS from your stylesheets. It works across multiple files and supports Javascript-injected CSS.

Optimization Step 6

Remove unused CSS

CSS:

~192 KB
→
~29KB

Minify CSS

remove comments and spaces

29 KB CSS file

Optimization Step 7

Minify CSS

  • cssminifier
  • gulp-minify-css
  • grunt-contrib-cssmin
  • …

Optimization Step 7

Minify CSS

CSS:

~29 KB
→
~21 KB

Inline critical CSS

above the fold CSS

Inlining the critical CSS (the CSS that’s necessary to display the above the fold content) and loading the rest asynchronously.

Optimization Step 8

Inline critical CSS

<script>
    loadCSS('style.css');
</script>

<style>
    /* critical css */
</style>

<noscript>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
</noscript>

Optimization Step 10

Uglify JS files

JS:

~397 KB
→
~153 KB

Move JS to the bottom of the page

or load it asynchronously

Javascript blocks rendering if loaded in the head-section on the page.

Font optimization

Font optimization

Font loading

Don’t load fonts with the <link> element, because it’s slow on first view and it blocks rendering.

Instead use Web Font Loader or Font Face Observer.

Font optimization

Web Font Loader

  • Developed by Google and Typekit
  • Loading of web fonts synchronously or asynchronously
  • Javascript events, e.g. fontloading
  • CSS classes, e.g. .wf-active
  • Doesn’t block rendering (if you want to)

http://google.com/fonts

Font optimization

Web Font Loader

WebFontConfig = {
  google: {
    families: ['Droid Sans']
  },
  loading: function() {},
  active: function() {},
  inactive: function() {},
  fontloading: function(familyName, fvd) {},
  fontactive: function(familyName, fvd) {},
  fontinactive: function(familyName, fvd) {}
};

Font optimization

Web Font Observer

  • Actually a tool for checking if a font exists
  • Checks by loading the font
  • Not as extensive as Web Font Loader
  • Callback function if font has loaded successfully

Font optimization

Web Font Observer

var fontA = new FontFaceObserver( "Cabin" );

Promise
    .all([fontA.check()])
    .then(function(){
        document.documentElement.className += "fonts-loaded";
    });

    .fonts-loaded body {
        font-family: 'Cabin', sans-serif;
    }

Font optimization

Subsetting

Remove the characters you won’t need before you embed the web font. You can do this when embedding fonts with Typekit or manually at Font Squirrel by using their Webfont Generator.

Font optimization

CDN

Use an hosted service or move your web fonts to a CDN (Content Delivery Network) like CloudFront.

Font optimization

Caching

Cache your fonts for as long as possible (e.g. a year).

Font optimization

WOFF/WOFF2

When embedding fonts use the formats WOFF and WOFF2. They are much better compressed than .ttf and the browser support is great for WOFF and OK for WOFF2.

Optimization Step 11

Load fonts with Web Font Observer

Desktop:

1964 → 1314

Mobile:

8407 → 5922

Caching & gzipping

Caching & gzipping

Caching

Every browser ships with an implementation of an HTTP cache. We just need provide the information what to cache and how long.

Caching & gzipping

Gzipping

GZIP performs best on text-based content, often achieving compression rates of as high as 70-90% for larger files

Ilya Grigorik

server stuff

eeewwww

HTML5 Boilerplate

reasonable settings & defaults

The HTML5 Boilerplate offers some great
Apache HTTP server boilerplate configs.

What else?

Serviceworker

Serviceworker

What is Serviceworker?

  • Background worker
  • Acts like a proxy server sitting on the client
  • Push notifications
  • Background Sync
  • Offline

Serviceworker

How do you use Serviceworker?

Serviceworker

How do you use Serviceworker?

  • Register a Serviceworker
  • Create cache and add resources
  • Fetch data from cache
  • Fetch data from network and update

Serviceworker

What is important to know?

  • HTTPS only (Test on Github, localhost)
  • Browser support (Chrome, Firefox, Opera)
  • Still in development

HTTP/2

HTTP/2

hard facts

  • HTTP/1.1 more than 15 years old
  • Based on Googles SPDY
  • Faster connection speeds
  • One connection for parallelism (no more sprites, concatenation, etc.)
  • HTTPS not necessarily mandatory (but for Firefox and Chrome it will be)
  • Read more in the HTTP/2 FAQ

Wrap-up

finally

  • Set a performance budget
  • Test and measure constantly
  • Optimize images, CSS and Javascript
  • Optimize font loading
  • Cache and gzip
  • Choose your tools and techniques wisely
  • Test!
